review.title: Leveraging Recurrent Neural Networks for Multimodal Recognition of Social Norm Violation in Dialog
review.abstract: Social norms are shared rules that govern and facilitate social interaction. Violating such social norms via teasing and insults may serve to upend power imbalances or, on the contrary reinforce solidarity and rapport in conversation, rapport which is highly situated and context-dependent. In this work, we investigate the task of automatically identifying the phenomena of social norm violation in discourse. Towards this goal, we leverage the power of recurrent neural networks and multimodal information present in the interaction, and propose a predictive model to recognize social norm violation. Using long-term temporal and contextual information, our model achieves an F1 score of 0.705. Implications of our work regarding developing a social-aware agent are discussed.

sections.heading: 2 Data and Annotation
sections.text: Mutual peer tutoring data was collected from 12 American English-speaking dyads (6 friends and 6 strangers; 6 boys and 6 girls), with an average age of 13 years, who interacted for five hours over as many weeks (a total of 60 sessions and 5400 minutes of data), teaching each other algebra. Each session began with a period of getting to know each other, after which the first tutoring period began, followed by another small social interlude, a second tutoring period with role swapping between the tutor and the tutee, and then the last social time.We evaluated our automatic recognition of the violation of social norms against these strategies. Interpreter Reliability (IRR) for the social norm violation calculated via Krippendorff's alpha, which we consider normal.

sections.heading: 3 Model and Experiment
sections.text: In this section, our goal was to develop a mathematical model for detecting violations of social norms. To this end, we first used each clause, the smallest units that can express a full sentence, as a predictive unit. Next, inspired by in-depth analysis in [14], we extracted verbal and visual characteristics of the speaker that were strongly correlated with clauses that violate social norms, setting the rare threshold to 20. Verbal characteristics included LIWC characteristics [5] that helped categorize words used during the use of violations of social norms, bigrams, parts of speech bigrams, and word components of speech pairs from the speaker clauses. Visual characteristics included head nodes, information about smiles, and moments of the speaker. In total, there were 3,782 characteristics per clause.

sections.heading: 3.1 Models
sections.text: We treated a dialogue D as a sequence of clauses c0,... cT, where T was the number of clauses in D. Each sentence ci was a tuple ([wi0,... w i m], ei), where [w i 0,... w i m] were the m words in the sentence ci, and ei was the corresponding meta-information such as the relationship of the dyad and nonverbal behavior during the generation of the sentence. The craftsmanship characteristic of size 3782 was called fi and could be considered a mapping function F: ci → fi. Meanwhile, each sentence was associated with a binary term yi с0, 1}, which indicates the basic truth about whether ci is a violation of the social norm. Ultimately, the goal was to model p (yt | c0: t), the conditional distribution of whether the last sentence was a violation of the social norm, given the entire history of the dialogue.

sections.heading: 3.1.1 Logistic Regression Model
sections.text: We first trained an L2-regulated logistic regression model using the proposed verbal and visual characteristics fi as input (far left in Figure 1), which serves as a starting point.

sections.heading: 3.1.2 Local/Global-Context RNN Model
sections.text: Past empirical results indicate two possible hypotheses for improving model performance: 1. Improving the representation of the clause level 2. Including contextual information for prediction. Therefore, we have designed local / global context models to test these hypotheses. The local context of recursive neural networks (RNN) models the context within a clause at the word level by sequentially encoding word embedding of size 300 in a clause using a long-short term memory (LSTM) cell of size 300. sections.heading: 3.2 Experiment Result
sections.text: We observed that Global-Context RNN with 2 LSTM layers outperformed other models, as shown in Table 2. First, comparing the logistic regression model with our best model shows that the result indicates the strong predictive power of long-term context information about the task of detecting social norm violations in dialogue. On the other hand, the Local-Context RNN model did not significantly improve overall performance in terms of logistic regression, meaning that our learned clause representation in the training process is less competent than handmade features inspired by language skills. A possible reason for such a result could be insufficient training scope to learn a generic sentence representation.

sections.heading: 4 Conclusion and Future Work
sections.text: Inspired by handcrafted multimodal characteristics derived from qualitative and quantitative analyses of previous empirical studies, we developed a Global Context RNN model for detecting violations of social norms in human dialogue. This model will play an important role in building socially aware actors who have the skills to understand interpersonal dynamics that unfold in interaction, which is indispensable for better adaptation to the interpersonal relationship of their users. To serve this goal, our future work will build a generative model of social norm violations that will allow an agent to act in the direction of a more realistic understanding, thinking and producing of human behavior.
